awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Structure-Functional Imaging of the Atrial Myocardium
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Hendon, Christine 
Proposal: 1454365

Atrial fibrillation (AF), the most common type of arrhythmia, is characterized by quivering of the atria due to unorganized electrical activity. Those with AF run the risk of stroke due to blood clots developed in the atria or heart failure from lack of pumped blood. This proposal focuses on improving ablation techniques used to treat atrial fibrillation through the addition of optical imaging systems. If successful, this would be the first real time imaging tool capable of assisting in this very common surgical procedure. The Educational Plan emphasizes activities designed to recruit more women and minority students into graduate level engineering program. The PIs will integrate this platform into their signal processing and instrumentation courses.  


The proposal focuses on improving ablation techniques used to treat atrial fibrillation through the addition of an optical imaging system using Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) and near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) to characterize fiber orientation and tissue composition, measure ablation depth, and determine if such information, along with functional electrical analysis, can be used to produce more efficacious lesions, i.e., ones that are not unnecessarily large or do not have to be redone. The PI will bring her expertise in optics and signal processing to bear on assessing therapy of atrial fibrillation using radiofrequency ablation. Using NIRS should provide a highly useful method for assessing RFA lesions. Preliminary data confirm that polarization sensitive OCT can detect fiber orientation, a key physiological parameter in assessing tissue functionality. The results show good potential for distinguishing healthy myocardium from fibrotic tissue. 

This award is co-funded by the Biophotonics program (CBET) in the Engineering Directorate and the Communications, Circuits, & Sensing Systems (ECCS) in the Engineering Directorate.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this CAREER Award has resulted in advancement of optical imaging and spectroscopy technology and processing development for applications in cardiac electrophysiology, training of a diverse set of graduate students, and broader impacts with STEM outreach and efforts towards increasing diversity within graduate education programs.

 

Cardiac arrhythmias are a major source of morbidity and mortality in the United States, where it is estimated that millions of people have arrhythmias that cannot be controlled with medications or devices. Since pharmacological therapies have limited effectiveness, catheter ablation directed at interrupting critical components of arrhythmia circuits has emerged as a prominent approach for the treatment of a broad range of atrial and ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Atrial fibrillation (AF), the most common type of arrhythmia, characterized by quivering of the atria due to unorganized electrical activity. Those with AF run the risk of stroke due to blood clots developed in the atria or heart failure from lack of pumped blood. It is therefore imperative for AF to be diagnosed properly to ensure adequate treatment is received before significant complications occur. Catheter ablation is attractive because it is the only therapy, which offers potential for cure rather than palliation of arrhythmias. Ablation using radiofrequency energy is now the standard of care for treatment of many arrhythmias. The goal of radiofrequency ablation is to target and destroy tissue that triggers or supports abnormal electrical pathways, while minimizing or avoiding damage to normal areas of the heart. 

 

It is my goal to develop tools for imaging the myocardium, which will provide cardiac electrophysiologist, cardiologist, and heart surgeons a view of the heart wall to aid in disease diagnosis and guide therapy. Towards this goal, within this CAREER award I demonstrated that optical imaging and spectroscopy can be as a means to monitor cardiac RFA therapy, by measuring lesion depth which is an important parameter to determine the likely success of an ablation procedure. There is typically an underlying substrate due to remodeling with the development of scar tissue or fibrosis that is the cause of the abnormalities in conduction patterns.  We mapped and characterize the fiber orientation and tissue composition of the human left and  right atria and pulmonary veins, developed algorithms to quantify tissue heterogeneity and presence of fibrosis and fat and measured radiofrequency ablation lesion depth. Custom catheters were prototyped, to verify that these measurements are possible within a living animal.  With this advance we have built the foundation for assessing RFA lesion dimensions by spectroscopy and characterizing important structure and architecture within the heart that can impact electrical function and conduction by OCT. This is the foundation to improvements in catheter designs and processing of optical signals to enable long term technological advances for more effective and efficacious monitoring and guidance of cardiac arrhythmia therapy. 

 

The research activities of this award addresses an area that has broad impact to our entire community by developing optical catheters and image analysis for improving the diagnosis and treatment of cardiovascular disease. The results from this work have been shared with the scientific community through conference presentations and journal publications. This awards has enabled me to provide laboratory tours and hands-on demonstrations of biomedical optics, optical coherence tomography and spectroscopy to middle and high school students in the New York City area. This CAREER award has also helped me to train a new group of engineers who are learning to integrate concepts from various disciplines to develop new high resolution imaging systems and real time image processing algorithms which will have a large impact on the fields of biomedical optics and medical imaging.
